title: Which company's processors are better: AMD or Intel? - Quora

response.answer_text: The most obvious difference is the company that develops and sells them. Intel processors are developed, manufactured and sold by Intel. AMD processors are developed and sold by AMD, and manufactured by TSMC or GlobalFoundries. (AMD pays for TSMC or Globalfoundries for manufacturing them) Technically, it then depends on the actual models of the processors. But lets assume we are comparing AMDs ryzen-series processors with Intels core i-series processors From high-level perspective, the differences are much smaller than the commonalities: The processors cores of both ryzen and core i-series processors are based on the exactly same principles; They run the same x86–86 instruction set, and their working principle is the same: They are speculative out-of-order-execution cores with Physical Register File(PRF)-type Out-Of-Order engine. They both also perform simultaneous MultiThreading (SMT). Intel calls it “HyperThreading”, but technically it’s exactly the same thing what AMD’s Ryzen does, “HyperThreading” is only Intels trademarked marketing name for SMT. However, from low-level perspective, they are totally different processors, everything has been designed separately by these two companies. It’s like comparing Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla: They look very similar, they may have the same number of wheels, same type of engine, same type of transmission, most of the controls and meters are in the exactly same place. Still, they are two totally different card that share no common parts, and the small details differences everywhere make them perform slightly differently But lets go to some of the most important actual differences that do have some effect on how they perform: L3 cache On Intel core i-series processors, the L3 cache is share by all the cores on the die. This means 2–8 cores on desktop processors and even 28 cores on some very expensive server models. Any of the cores can use the whole cache for itself, and if some core has loaded the data to the L3 cache, others can immediately use it. On AMD ryzen, maximum of 4 cores share the L3 cache; On 8-core desktop model there are two separate 16 MiB L3 caches, and on a 64-core AMD server processors, there are 16 separate 16 MiB L3 caches. Sharing the L3 cache with only 3 cores makes the L3 cache faster for these 4 cores, but if a fifth core wants to access the same data that is in the L3 cache of some other 4 cores, it has to copy the data to its own L3 cache first, and single thread can only benefit from it’s own 16 megabyte L3 cache. For single thread, the L3 cache works like it’s size was only 16 megabytes even though there is total of 256 MiB of L3 in 64-core AMD server processor. On the next “zen3” generation which will be released at the end of 2020, AMD will move into architecture where 8 cores will share and L3 cache, instead of the current 4. Monolitic die vs “chiplets (multiple dies in a package, MCM)” All the Intel core i-series CPUs, and AMDs mobile ryzen models consist of a single die. But AMDs zen2-based server and desktop processors (ryzen 3000-series without iGPU) consist of multiple chips in the same package. Using these multiple chips allow AMD to make versions with higher core counts with reasonable cost, even 16 on desktop 3950X and 64 on some servger models, and to use cheaper and older “12nm” or “14nm” manufacturing process for non-performance-critical parts (IO functionality) while producing the CPU cores with the most advanced “7nm” manufacturing process. However, having the memory controller and CPU cores on different dies adds some memory latency, which have slight negative effect on performance. To offset this, AMD uses (multiple) huge 16 MiB L3 caches in these destop and server zen2 models.
